segments.text: James Pappas is here today and he's thrilled to death that he's here.
In fact, on spring break, he wanted to stay up here.
He loves A&M.
But I think they need to intermingle a little bit more with the former students because I'm here on this Saul Ross reunion.
I'm disappointed in the turnout.
And I don't know why.
We talked about it last night.
Like you, they asked me at the hospitality room, what can we do to get more people involved?
I don't know.
But I think the administration needs to get out into the field a little bit more instead of staying here.
And Ray Bowen has done a great job, outstanding job.
I'll do whatever Ray Bowen wants to do.
I'll support him and always have and always will.
He's such a fine person.
But I think they need to get out and just socialize a little bit more, as we say, in quotes, socialize, you know.
And to get the former students, because pretty soon my classmates like me are passing on and we need the younger group.
If someone walked up to you and handed you a check for a million dollars with one condition on it, you must pass that check on to A&M.
If you had the capability to make a major gift to A&M, for what purpose would you want that money used?
Scholarships.
For whom?
For a deserving student.
Now, I'm not going to set any parameters about IQs and SATs and stuff like that.
Because there are a lot of deserving kids out there who don't have SAT over 1150 or 1200 but who deserve scholarships.
How do you decide that they deserve it?
How would you measure that deserving?
By interview?
by contact, by background checks on them, and I'm happy to say that my brothers and I have had a Presidential Endowed Scholarship for the last twenty years.
Does it matter what the student majors in?
It does not matter.
It does not matter.
Or whether it's he or she or where they're from?
three, the last four we had were females.
This one is a male, first male we had.
And he's on the track team, he's a javelin thrower, and his grades are, he passes the marks and everything.
And we're happy about that.
I'm about through now, but I'm thinking about a few other things.
Of all your Aggie memories, of what are you most proud?
other than the fact that you came here.
I came here and I graduated.
Well I'm proud, I really am proud that A&M designated me as a distinguished student and distinguished alumni in 1996.
That was the biggest surprise
I've had about A&M.
And that tells me A&M doesn't seek those with money resources or what.
They're seeking a person who likes A&M, who will contribute to A&M, which I will do and have done.
And also, when I captained the A&M basketball team, I was honored by that.
I'm honored that I was the second and third president of the Texas, of the A&M's Letterman Association, helped build that, helped get that going back in the 70s.
And I'm delighted that I went to A&M because it helped me become a general.
A general's a general.
And I had no idea when I came to A&M about even liking the military, but I was going to do it.
And here, some 40, 50 years later, I'm a general officer status, and it just makes me proud that A&M had all to do with it, to tell you the truth.
Because A&M is looked upon throughout the world.
as great leaders and great patriots.
During World War II, we had 17,000 officers.
And I presume that you saw a number of Aggies in Europe during the war.
I did.
Oh, yeah.
I saw a bunch.
Did you, by chance, run into Earl Rutter during the war?
No, sir, but I served under General Rutter in the reserve.
He was commander of the 9th Division, and I was one of his battalion commanders.
I commanded the artillery battalion.
him and a great guy.
His assistant was Graber Kidwell from Dallas and he was my artillery commander, General Kidwell.
But General Rudder was down to earth, smart, let you do your job.
He always said,
You're the artillery man.
Do your job.
Do your work.
Yes, sir, General.
But, yeah, great guy.
I've got only one more question I can think of.
Have we left anything out that you want to be sure we include about you and A&M?
Can't think of anything that, I think we covered it pretty well.
You have covered it pretty well.
Then the last question is, what feelings do you carry in your heart for Texas A&M today?
You want me to cry?
I can cry with A&M.
I'm about to do it now.
Great, great school.
In my heart, A&M will stand with my father and mother.
That's how strong I feel about A&M.
Let's quit with that.
